contextId.information: Expressions of arrogance on people's faces are spoken of as if the expressions were persons who could testify against the proud people. AT: "The prideful looks on their faces show that they oppose Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: The look on their faces witnesses against them

contextId.information: Isaiah speaks of the king of Assyria and his army as if he were one man. AT: "the king of Assyria and his army" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: the Assyrian

contextId.information: The word "He" refers to "the Assyrian," a personification of the king of Assyria and his army. The words "rod" and "staff" refer to pieces of wood that people use as clubs to beat animals and other people. Isaiah speaks of the way the Assyrians will rule over the Israelites as if the Assyrians were beating the Israelites with clubs. AT: "The Assyrians will rule over you and make slaves of you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: He will strike you with the rod and raise his staff against you

contextId.information: People suddenly feeling terrible pain and sorrow is spoken of as if the pains and sorrows were people who grab them. AT: "they will suddenly feel terrible pain and agony" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: pain and agony will seize them

contextId.information: Isaiah speaks of the trees as if they were people who could rejoice. This emphasizes that it is such a great thing that God has stopped the king of Babylon that even nature would rejoice if it could. AT: "It will be as if even the cyprus trees and the cedars of Lebanon rejoice over you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: Even the cypress trees rejoice over you with the cedars of Lebanon

contextId.information: Sheol is spoken of as if it were a person who is eager to meet his guests. This implies that the king dies. AT: "Sheol is like a host eager to meet you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: Sheol below is eager to meet you

contextId.information: The idols are described as having feelings of fear as Yahweh approaches. AT: "the idols of Egypt tremble in fear before Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: the idols of Egypt quake before him

contextId.information: The nation of Egypt is spoken of here as if it was a person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: The spirit of Egypt will be weakened from within. I will destroy his advice

contextId.information: Here "her" refers to Egypt. Nations are sometimes spoken of as if they were women. AT: "within Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: into her midst

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) Yahweh describes the city of Tyre as a mother who speaks about the people who live in the city as her children, or 2) Yahweh is describing the Mediterranean Sea as speaking. The people of Tyre considered the sea their god and father. In either meaning the speaker mourns because its children are destroyed. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: for the sea has spoken, the mighty one of the sea ... nor brought up young women

contextId.information: The sun and the moon are described as a person who is ashamed of being in front of someone with greater power. In the presence of Yahweh, the light of the moon and sun will seem less bright. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: Then the moon will be ashamed, and the sun disgraced

contextId.information: Isaiah describes "justice" and "righteousness" as a person who lives in these places. This means the people who live in these places will do what is just and right. AT: "people will act justly in the wilderness and people will act righteously in the fertile fields (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: justice will reside ... righteousness will live

contextId.information: This speaks of the land becoming dry as if it were a person mourning. AT: "The land becomes dry and its plants wither away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: The land mourns and withers away

contextId.information: These two phrases have basically the same meaning. These places are described as being glad, like a person is glad, because they have received water and are blossoming. AT: "It will be like the wilderness and the Arabah are glad and the desert will rejoice" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: The wilderness and the Arabah will be glad; and the desert will rejoice

contextId.information: The prophet speaks of Jerusalem as if it were a woman whom Yahweh has forgiven. As such, Jerusalem represents the people who live in that city. AT: Speak tenderly to the people of Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Speak tenderly to Jerusalem

contextId.information: The writer speaks of Zion as if it were a messenger who declares good news from a mountain top. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: Go up on a high mountain, Zion, bearer of good news

contextId.information: Yahweh speaks to "the north" and "the south" as if commanding the nations in those locations. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: say to the north ... to the south

contextId.information: Isaiah turns his attention from the people of Israel and speaks to the heavens, earth, and mountains as if they were people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_apostrophe]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: Sing, heavens, and be joyful, earth; break into singing, you mountains!

contextId.information: The word "Zion" is another name for Jerusalem. Isaiah speaks of the city as if it were a woman who complains that Yahweh has forgotten her. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: But Zion said

contextId.information: The word "her" refers to Zion. Cities are often spoken of as if they were women. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: her waste places ... her wilderness ... her desert plains

contextId.information: People urgently ask Yahweh's arm to help them as if his arm were a person. If it would be odd to speak to the arm, this can be addressed directly to Yahweh instead. AT: "Awake, awake, Yahweh, and clothe your arm with strength" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: Awake, awake, clothe yourself with strength, arm of Yahweh

contextId.information: Isaiah speaks of the ruins of Jerusalem as if they were a person that could rejoice. This represents the people of Jerusalem who were defeated. AT: "you people who live among the ruins of Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: you ruins of Jerusalem

contextId.information: Isaiah describes the sins as a person who goes before God to declare that the people are guilty. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: our sins testify against us

contextId.information: "hidden from my eyes" represents the attention and memory of Yahweh. AT: "I will not even think about them again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: they will be hidden from my eyes
